key_risks: License change backlash impacting developer and enterprise trust
Intense competition from cloud providers like AWS, Azure, and GCP
Revenue concentration from a small number of large customers
Market saturation in search, analytics, and observability sectors
controversies: Transition from open-source to proprietary licenses causing community backlash
Competition with AWS's OpenSearch due to the license change
social_issues: Ethical concerns over the shift away from open-source principles
governance_issues: Potential reputational damage from the license change controversy

sources.title: Amazon: NOT OK - why we had to change Elastic licensing
sources.snippet: We recently announced a license change: Blog, FAQ. We posted some additional guidance on the license change this morning. I wanted to share why we had to make this change. sources.title: Elastic founder on why they returned to open source 4 years after going ...
sources.snippet: Elastic, the company behind Elasticsearch, has reverted to open source nearly four years after adopting proprietary licenses. This decision follows a trademark dispute with AWS, which had marketed its own version of Elasticsearch. sources.title: Two Ways of Interpreting the Elastic License Change - ITPro Today
sources.snippet: The Elastic license change is terrible for open source. One is to view this as a major retreat by Elastic--and, by extension, the open source community in general--in the face of the cloud. Open source has long had a strained relationship with the cloud due to the fundamental design of cloud services.
